# loading packages

```{r}
library(tidyverse)
library(psych)
library(MBESS)
library(lavaan)
library(semTools)
library(palmerpenguins)
library(faux)
library(skimr)
library(here)
library(responsesR)
```


# R Version

```{r}
sessionInfo()
```



# First data set

Simulating correlated data

```{r}
mydata1 <- dat <- rnorm_multi(n = 800, 
                              mu = c(3.4, 3.5, 3.6, 3.7),
                              sd = c(0.9, 1, 1.1, 1.2),
                              r = c(.5, .55, .6, .65, .7, .75), 
                              varnames = c("A", "B", "C", "D"),
                              empirical = FALSE)

skim(mydata1)
```



## psych package

```{r}
psych::omega(mydata1)
psych::omega(mydata1, nfactors = 1)
```


## mbess

```{r}
MBESS::ci.reliability(data = mydata1, type = "omega")
```


## semtools

Following decision tree (Fig. 4) in paper <https://doi.org/10.1177/2515245920951747>, we need to compute $\omega_u$ **for a one dimensional model** with continuous variables **with 5 or more response options**.

![](`r here("www/decision_tree.jpeg")`)

```{r}
model <- 'ABC =~ A + 
                 B + 
                 C + 
                 D'

fit_m <- cfa(model, 
             data = mydata1, 
             std.lv=T, 
             missing='direct', 
             estimator='MLR')

reliability(fit_m)
```
